definition: everything you can see when you look across a large area of land, especially in the country
a painting of a view of the countryside; this style of painting
the characteristic features of an area of activity
the way of printing a document in which the top of the page is one of the longer sides
an object, especially an ugly building, that makes a place less beautiful
a mass of earth, rock, etc. that falls down the slope of a mountain or a cliff
an election in which one person or party gets very many more votes than the other people or parties

a device that gives out light in which all the waves oscillate (= change direction and strength) together, typically producing a powerful beam of light that can be used for cutting metal, in medical operations, etc.
a flat green part of a plant, growing from a stem or branch or from the root
having leaves of the type or number mentioned
a sheet of paper, especially a page in a book
metal, especially gold or silver, in the form of very thin sheets
a part of a table that can be lifted up, or an extra section that can be added into the table, in order to make the table bigger
to copy somebody’s behaviour and do things in the same way that they do, because they are successful
to change your way of life to become a better, more responsible person
an amount of liquid or gas escaping through a hole in something; an occasion when there is a leak
material made by removing the hair or fur from animal skins and preserving the skins using special processes
clothes made from leather, especially those worn by people riding motorcycles
as quickly as possible
a law or a set of laws passed by a parliament
the process of making and passing laws
a group of people who have the power to make and change laws
an extra amount of money that has to be paid, especially as a tax to the government
all the words and phrases used in a particular language or subject; all the words and phrases used and known by a particular person or group of people
a list of words on a particular subject or in a language in alphabetical order
a dictionary, especially one of an ancient language, such as Greek or Hebrew
the state of being legally responsible for something
a person or thing that causes you a lot of problems
the amount of money that a person or company owes
a building in which collections of books, newspapers, etc. and sometimes films and recorded music are kept for people to read, study or borrow
a collection of books, newspapers, films, recorded music, etc. held in a library or stored in digital form
a room in a large house where most of the books are kept
a personal collection of books, music recordings, etc.
a series of books, recordings, etc. produced by the same company and similar in appearance
a very small grey or yellow plant that spreads over the surface of rocks, walls and trees and does not have any flowers
the way in which a person or a group of people lives and works
the energy from the sun, a lamp, etc. that makes it possible to see things
a particular type of light with its own colour or qualities
a thing that produces light, especially an electric light
an expression in somebody’s eyes that shows what they are thinking or feeling
light colours in a picture, which contrast with darker ones
a match or device with which you can light a cigarette
a window or an opening to allow light in
according to the standards that somebody sets for himself or herself
to be between somebody and a source of light
to go to sleep very quickly
to be pleasant, friendly and polite
to be fun and easy to deal with
the excitement of city life
to make new information known to people
to make a problem, etc. easier to understand
to become known to people
to not let people know that you are good at something
when you have had time to think calmly about something; in the morning when things are clearer
if you see something or put something in a good, bad, etc. light, it seems good, bad, etc.
after considering something
to fail to stop at a red traffic light
something that shows you are nearly at the end of a long and difficult time or situation
somebody suddenly understood or began to understand something
the person somebody loves more than any other
used to describe somebody who is stupid, not thinking clearly or not paying attention
to finally understand or accept something, especially something obvious
to begin to believe in a religion
to begin to exist or to become publicly known about
to make something start burning
the arrangement or type of light in a place
the use of electric lights in a place
a soft brown type of coal
a white substance obtained by heating limestone, used in building materials and to help plants grow
a small green fruit, like a lemon, with juice that has a bitter, sharp taste, used in cooking and in drinks; the juice of this fruit
a tree on which limes grow
a large tree with light-green, heart-shaped leaves and yellow flowers
a bright yellow-green colour
a type of white rock that contains calcium, used in building and in making cement
any of a group of natural substances that do not dissolve in water, including plant oils and steroids
pieces of writing that are valued as works of art, especially novels, plays and poems (in contrast to technical books and newspapers, magazines, etc.)
pieces of writing or printed information on a particular subject
the layer of rock that forms the outer part of the earth
small pieces of rubbish such as paper, cans and bottles, that people have left lying in a public place
a number of things that are lying in an untidy way
a dry substance that is put in a shallow open box for pets, especially cats, to use as a toilet when they are indoors
a number of baby animals that one mother gives birth to at the same time
the substance, especially straw, that is used for farm animals to sleep on
a kind of chair or bed that was used in the past for carrying important people
near the coast; connected with the coast
the animals kept on a farm, for example cows or sheep
a reptile with a long body and tail, four short legs and a rough skin. There are many different types of lizard.
a railway engine that pulls a train
a large vehicle for carrying heavy loads by road
goods that fell off the back of a lorry were probably stolen. People say or accept that they came ‘off the back of a lorry’ to avoid saying or asking where they really came from.
the state of no longer having something or as much of something; the process that leads to this
money that has been lost by a business or an organization
the death of a person
the disadvantage that is caused when somebody leaves, or when a useful or valuable object is taken away; a person who causes a disadvantage by leaving
a failure to win a contest
not knowing what to say or do
in a way that loses you money
used to say that if somebody chooses not to do something, they will not obtain a benefit they could have had
to stop doing something that is not successful before the situation becomes even worse
the state of being less respected by other people or looking stupid because of something you have done
how loud something is
the fact of making a lot of noise
a substance, for example oil, that you put on surfaces or parts of a machine so that they move easily and smoothly
the fact of shining in the dark; the ability to give out light
a clear and beautiful quality that something has
a strongly alkaline chemical used in various industrial processes, including washing
the study of large economic systems, such as those of whole countries or areas of the world
a physical property (= characteristic) of some metals such as iron, produced by electric currents, that causes forces between objects, either pulling them towards each other or pushing them apart
the qualities of something, especially a person’s character, that people find powerful and attractive
a serious disease that causes a high temperature and shivering (= shaking of the body) caused by the bite of some types of mosquito
a part of the body that is not formed correctly
the state of not being correctly formed
a poor condition of health caused by a lack of food or a lack of the right type of food
any animal that gives birth to live young, not eggs, and feeds its young on milk. Cows, humans and whales are all mammals.
the activity of running and controlling a business or similar organization
the people who run and control a business or similar organization
the act or skill of dealing with people or situations in a successful way
the authority to do something, given to a government or other organization by the people who vote for it in an election
the period of time for which a government is given power
an official order given to somebody to perform a particular task
the power given to a country to govern another country or region, especially in the past
a tropical tree that grows in mud or at the edge of rivers and has roots that are above ground
the number of workers needed or available to do a particular job
the waste matter from animals that is spread over or mixed with the soil to help plants and crops grow
